revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Colin Richard Keppel |image= CommodoreColinRichardKeppel.jpg |caption= Commodore Colin Keppel, taken at the inspection of the fleet off Cowes 1907 |birth_date= {{birth date|1862|12|03|df=yes}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1947|07|06|1862|12|03|df=yes}} |birth_place= |death_place= [[Winkfield]], Berkshire |nickname= |allegiance= United Kingdom |branch= [[Royal Navy]] |serviceyears= 1875–1913 |rank= [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] |unit= |commands= [[Royal Yacht Squadron|Rear Admiral Commanding HM Yachts]] (1905–09)
[[HMY Victoria and Albert (1899)|HMY ''Victoria and Albert'']] (1905)
{{HMS|Implacable|1899|6}} (1904–05)
{{HMS|Grafton|1892|6}} (1901–03)
{{HMS|Warspite|1884|6}} (1900–01)
{{HMS|Rainbow|1891|6}} (1900)
{{HMS|Harrier|1894|6}} (1897)
{{HMS|Skipjack||6}} (1896–97) |battles= [[Mahdist War]] |awards= [[Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order]]
[[Knight Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire]]
[[Companion of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Distinguished Service Order]]
[[Order of Saint Stanislaus|Order of Saint Stanislaus, 1st Class]] (Russia)
[[Order of the Red Eagle|Order of the Red Eagle, 2nd Class]] (Prussia) |laterwork= }} [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] '''Sir Colin Richard Keppel''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|GCVO|KCIE|CB|DSO}} (3 December 1862 – 6 July 1947) was a British sailor and [[Extra Equerry]] to four kings. ==Background== He was the son of Admiral [[Henry Keppel|Sir Henry Keppel]], younger son of [[William Keppel, 4th Earl of Albemarle]], and his second wife Jane Elizabeth West, daughter of Martin John West.{{cite book | last = Fox-Davies | first = Arthur Charles | title = Armorial Families | location = London | publisher = Hurst & Blackett | volume = vol. II | year = 1929 | pages = 1092 }} His paternal uncles were [[Augustus Keppel, 5th Earl of Albemarle]] and [[George Keppel, 6th Earl of Albemarle]], his maternal uncle was [[Algernon Edward West|Sir Algernon Edward West]]. He was educated at [[Temple Grove]] and entered the Royal Navy as cadet on the training ship [[HMS Britannia (1820)|HMS ''Britannia'']] in 1875.{{cite web | url = http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cgi-bin/vcdf/detail?coll_id=537&inst_id=21&nv1=search&nv2= | title = AIM25 – KEPPEL, Adm Sir Colin (Richard) (1862–1947) | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} ==Naval career== [[File:Colin Richard Keppel Vanity Fair 3 March 1909.JPG|right|thumb|Keppel caricatured by [[Leslie Ward|Spy]] for [[Vanity Fair (British magazine)|Vanity Fair]], 1909]] ===Early years=== Keppel served on [[HMS Sultan (1870)|HMS ''Sultan'']] in the [[British Mediterranean Fleet]] until 1878 and was then transferred as midshipman to [[HMS Black Prince (1861)|HMS ''Black Prince'']], the world's second ship with an iron hull. He was aboard on [[HMS Wolverine (1863)|HMS'' Wolverine'']] in [[Sydney]] in the next year and was with [[HMS Inconstant (1868)|HMS ''Inconstant'']] in Asia until 1882. With the outbreak of the [[Mahdist War]], he was moved to [[HMS Duke of Wellington (1852)|HMS ''Duke of Wellington'']], the Commander-in-Chief's flagship in Portsmouth, then to [[HMS Iris (1877)|HMS ''Iris'']], one of the first all steel ships, until 1884. Subsequently, Keppel was promoted sub-lieutenant of [[HMS Invincible (1869)|HMS ''Invincible'']]. He served further on [[HMS Hibernia (1804)|HMS ''Hibernia'']] and became lieutenant on [[HMS Alexandria|HMS ''Alexandria'']] in 1885. A year later, Keppel was appointed equerry and flag lieutenant to [[Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]] until 1893 and was then transferred to [[HMS Pearl (1890)|HMS ''Pearl'']]. He was with [[HMY Royal George|HMY ''Royal George'']] in Portsmouth until 1895, became afterwards commander and sailed with [[HMS Skipjack|HMS ''Skipjack'']] to Gibraltar and with the torpedo gunboat [[HMS Harrier (1894)|''HMS Harrier'']] to Crete in 1897. ===On the Nile=== In October of that year, on loan to the Egyptian Government, he commanded three gunboats on the Nile, which were despatched from the town of [[Berber, Sudan]], recently captured by British forces commanded by [[Herbert Kitchener]], south to attack [[Metemma, Sudan]], which was held by Dervishes. At dawn on 16 October the ships attacked enemy troops at [[Shendi]], before shelling three forts on the bank of the Nile near Metamma, capturing some ships loaded with grain and then retiring. They returned the following day to discover the defences had been reinforced with more artillery, but continued the bombardment from beyond range of the enemy guns. Estimated Arab losses were 500 men, with one Soudanese soldier being killed on one of the gunboats.{{cite book | author = [[Winston Churchill]] | title = [[The River War]] (Volume 1)| publisher = Longmans Green and Co. | year = 1899 | place = London | pages = 347–350 }} Soon afterwards in the beginning of 1898, Keppel was as result awarded a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] and decorated with the [[Distinguished Service Order]].{{cite book | title = Whitaker's Peerage, Baronetage, Knightage and Companioage | publisher = J. Whitaker & Sons | year = 1923 | pages = 460 }} ===Admiral=== For his services in [[Sudan]], he received the thanks of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] in June 1899{{cite book | title = Who is Who 1947 | publisher = Adam & Charles Black Ltd. | location = London | year = 1947 | pages = 1518 }} and became captain{{ LondonGazette | issue = 27087 | startpage = 3588 | date = 6 June 1899 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} commanding [[HMS Wildfire (1888)|HMS ''Wildfire'']]. Keppel was transferred to [[HMS Spartan (1891)|HMS ''Spartan'']] in the same year and to newly launched cruiser {{HMS|Rainbow|1891|6}} in 1900. He subsequently commanded [[HMS Warspite (1884)|HMS ''Warspite'']], and when that ship was relieved as flagship on the [[Pacific Station]] by [[HMS Grafton (1892)|HMS ''Grafton'']] in March 1902, he transferred to ''Grafton'' as flag captain to [[Andrew Bickford|Sir Andrew Bickford]], Commander-in-Chief of that station.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence|day_of_week=Saturday |date=14 December 1901 |page_number=12 |issue=36638| }} In 1905 he commanded the battleship [[HMS Implacable (1899)|HMS ''Implacable'']] and was appointed commodore of the [[Royal Yacht Squadron]]. Keppel was awarded a [[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] in 1906 and,{{ LondonGazette | issue = 27918 | startpage = 3843 | date = 1 June 1906 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} after being promoted to rear admiral in 1908,{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28164 | startpage = 5731 | date = 4 August 1908 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} he was advanced to a Knight Commander.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28151 | startpage = 4644 | supp = yes | date = 23 June 1908 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} He became second in command of the [[British Atlantic Fleet]] in 1909 and was first on [[HMS Albemarle (1901)|HMS ''Albemarle'']], later on [[HMS London (1899)|HMS ''London'']]. In 1911, he led [[RMS Medina (1911)|RMS ''Medina'']] on a voyage to India and was afterwards invested a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire]].{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28559 | startpage = 9631 | date = 8 December 1911 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} Keppel was promoted vice admiral in 1913,{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28780 | startpage = 9083 | date = 9 December 1913 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} retiring few days later.{{LondonGazette | issue = 28783 | startpage = 9338 | date = 19 December 1913 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} He was made a full admiral in 1917.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 30037 | startpage = 3955 | date = 27 April 1917 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} Keppel received the 1st Class of the Russian [[Order of Saint Stanislaus (Imperial House of Romanov)|Order of St Stanislaus]] and the 2nd Class of the Prussian [[Order of the Red Eagle]]. ==Further career== Keppel served as [[Aide-de-Camp]] to [[King Edward VII]] from 1907 until the following year and as Extra Equerry from 1909. After the king's death in 1910, Keppel was Extra Equerry to his successor [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] until 1912.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28383 | startpage = 4075 | date = 10 June 1910 | accessdate =27 July 2009 }} Keppel was nominated [[Equerry-in-Ordinary]] in 1913,{{ LondonGazette | issue = 28678 | startpage = 37 | date = 3 January 1913 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} fulfilling this office for two years until his relinquishment in 1915, when he was again appointed Extra Equerry.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 29177 | startpage = 5205 | date = 1 June 1915 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} Subsequently he held this post also to [[King Edward VIII]]{{ LondonGazette | issue = 34306 | startpage = 4664 | date = 20 July 1936 | supp = yes | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} and [[King George VI]] until 1937.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 34376 | startpage = 1406 | date = 2 March 1937 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} Keppel became [[Serjeant-at-Arms]] of the [[British House of Commons]] in 1915,{{ LondonGazette | issue = 29133 | startpage = 3718 | date = 16 April 1915 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} resigning after twenty years.{{ LondonGazette | issue = 34203 | startpage = 6136 | date = 1 October 1935 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} In 1929, he was appointed a [[Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order]].{{ LondonGazette | issue = 33566 | supp = yes | startpage = 6 | date = 31 December 1929 | accessdate =26 July 2009 }} ==Family== On 6 June 1889, he married Mary Blundell-Hollinshead-Blundell, daughter of Major General Richard Blundell-Hollinshead-Blundell, and had by her two daughters. Marie, the older, was wife of Charles Marsham, 6th Earl of Romney, while her younger sister Melita had married [[Maurice Hely-Hutchinson]]. Keppel died at his country residence, Grove Lodge, at [[Winkfield]] Row in [[Berkshire]], aged 84 in 1947; his wife died ten years later.{{cite web|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p8343.htm#i83428|title=ThePeerage: Admiral Sir Colin Richard Keppel|accessdate=16 December 2006}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Commons category|Colin Richard Keppel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Keppel, Colin Richard}} [[Category:1862 births]] [[Category:1947 deaths]] [[Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Equerries]] [[Category:Keppel family|Colin Richard Keppel]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire]] [[Category:Knights Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Saint Stanislaus (Russian)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Eagle]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals]] [[Category:Royal Navy personnel of the Mahdist War]] [[Category:People from Winkfield]]
